body: FTR here are the changes we've done the last time we updated protobuf submodule: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/15114
~~mac failures are caused by https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/15600, we need to re-run after fixing.~~ I respawned the tests.

```
[microbenchmarks] Performance differences noted:
Benchmark                                                            cpu_time    real_time
-------------------------------------------------------------------  ----------  -----------
BM_PumpStreamServerToClient<InProcess>/32768                         +4%         +4%
BM_UnaryPingPong<InProcess, NoOpMutator, NoOpMutator>/262144/262144  +5%         +5%
BM_UnaryPingPong<MinInProcess, NoOpMutator, NoOpMutator>/0/262144    +8%         +8%
BM_Zalloc/512                                                        +4%         +4%
```
It looks like "Artifact Build Linux" failed because it attempts to build with GCC 4.7.2, which does not have full support for C++11. Does gRPC still need to support that version?

In some Python tests I also see this kind of error:
`TypeError: __new__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'serialized_options'`
I believe this indicates that the test must be mixing new generated code with an older runtime, which is not supported. In this [commit](https://github.com/google/protobuf/commit/0400cca3236de1ca303af38bf81eab332d042b7c) we added that serialized_options argument in `python/google/protobuf/descriptor.py`.

@acozzette   ad the protoc artifact builds:
we are using and old linux distro to build protoc artifacts to make sure the resulting binaries are compatible with a large range of linux distros. We can change the way the protoc artifacts are built, but it's not completely trivial and requires some extra testing.
https://source.cloud.google.com/results/invocations/2d1acfd4-db7d-4ada-a30f-97398174461f/targets/github%2Fgrpc/tests

About mixing older runtime with new generated code: I think you are correct, but we can't really test the new generated code with new runtime in python without having access to the new python protobuf packages - so in python's case we'll probably need to take a leap of faith, as we don't have the release candidate packages right now.

There's also a nanopb failure:
```
++ basename src/proto/grpc/lb/v1/load_balancer.proto
+ protoc --plugin=protoc-gen-nanopb=/var/local/git/grpc/third_party/nanopb/generator/protoc-gen-nanopb '--nanopb_out=-T -L#include\ \"third_party/nanopb/pb.h\":/tmp/tmp.f0nV74llsl' load_balancer.proto
         ********************************************************************
         *** Failed to import the protocol definitions for generator.     ***
         *** You have to run 'make' in the nanopb/generator/proto folder. ***
         ********************************************************************
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/var/local/git/grpc/third_party/nanopb/generator/nanopb_generator.py", line 33, in <module>
    import proto.nanopb_pb2 as nanopb_pb2
  File "/var/local/git/grpc/third_party/nanopb/generator/proto/nanopb_pb2.py", line 26, in <module>
    dependencies=[google_dot_protobuf_dot_descriptor__pb2.DESCRIPTOR,])
TypeError: __new__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'serialized_options'
--nanopb_out: protoc-gen-nanopb: Plugin failed with status code 1.
```
https://source.cloud.google.com/results/invocations/a347bc9b-633d-46dc-8dd0-5af841752eee/targets/github%2Fgrpc%2Fsanity_linux_dbg_native/tests


Besides this, I see a distribtest failure, but that one can be relatively easily fixed by upgrading the cmake version in our dockerimage
https://source.cloud.google.com/results/invocations/2345720c-f8f8-4711-ae12-a1520766891b/log

@acozzette   if we come up with a good explanation for the nanopb problem mentioned above, I think I should be relatively safe to tag the 3.6.0 release for protobuf and release the protobuf packages for all languages.  I can't guarantee everything will go smooth, but we should be able to bump our third_party/protobuf submodule to 3.6.0 without too many problems.

The failed windows distribtest raises some concern if protobuf builds well with on Windows with VS2015  https://source.cloud.google.com/results/invocations/501a62be-2043-4aa3-81bb-ec499e43b763/targets/github%2Fgrpc/tests

@jtattermusch Thanks for all the info! That nanopb problem looks like an instance of the same problem with the other Python tests (mixing new generated code with old runtime), so that may be OK. I'll look at the Windows error in just a minute.

@jtattermusch I haven't been able to figure out what caused the VS2015 build failure. It's strange because it shows a bunch of errors inside system headers like cmath. That makes me think something must be wrong with the C++11 setup. Maybe the build is somehow mixing C++98 and C++11 code in an incompatible way?

```
[microbenchmarks] Performance differences noted:
Benchmark                                      cpu_time    real_time
---------------------------------------------  ----------  -----------
BM_PumpStreamClientToServer<InProcess>/262144  +4%         +4%
```
